thread.title: Optus closing the gap on Telstra
thread.title_full: Optus closing the gap on Telstra | Business Spectator

author: David Swan
title: Optus closing the gap on Telstra
text:
Telstra has retained its position as Australia’s highest performing mobile network though Optus is closing the gap, according to a new report.
A benchmark test measuring smartphone voice and data performance around the country has shown Telstra scored highest across almost all categories, scoring highly in voice and data categories in both major metro locations and regional areas.
Australia’s second largest telco Optus is closing the gap on Telstra however, recording a 27 per cent improvement on its 2014 score that it puts down to network improvements including 700Mhz 4G Plus spectrum and an investment of more than $1.5 billion in its mobile network. It had a particularly strong data performance on highways.
The telcos were embroiled in a legal battle last year over their respective network coverage, with Telstra winning a Victorian Supreme Court battle after Optus said in advertisements it had similar coverage to Telstra. Telstra successfully argued those advertisements were “false, misleading and deceptive.”
Vodafone, which came in third place overall, improved on its 2014 score by just under 40 per cent. Telstra improved by 7 per cent, a mild improvement that was reflective of its strong 2014 scores.
The results come from the P3 CommsDay Mobile Benchmark 2015, a test conducted by German consulting and testing services firm P3 communications that involved specially equipped vehicles driving across areas that represented around 70 per cent of the Australian population.
CommsDay said all three operators should be pleased with their year-on-year improvements, and said further improvements could be expected next year as Telstra Optus and Vodafone each roll out their LTE capabilities, which should lead to fewer dropouts and much faster call setup times.
The smartphones used for testing were the Samsung S5 Cat 4 smartphone for voice testing and the Samsung Note 4 Cat 6 smartphone for data, running commercially available firmware.
This article was first published in The Australian Business Review.
